title: Why is high school a waste of time? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because it was created on a faulty premise and is a large government bureaucracy resistant to change. Certain special interest groups, like the teachers unions fight change. But more importantly, deep down most Americans aren’t willing to change it much either. The school system is very similar to what it was 100 years ago in many ways. We imported it from Prussia in the 1850s, with many of the characteristics we know today: age cohorts, rigid class structures and schedules, professionally trained teachers who led the classroom etc. At first, there was only the early grades, elementary school, and they focused on teaching basic skills like reading, writing and arithmetic. For the three Rs this “shut-up-and-do-as-I-say” approach worked quite well. Everyone should know how to read, write and do arithmetic, so it makes sense to have a standardized process for it. These skills can also be evaluated somewhat well through tests, which can also provide students motivation to improve. With this success, they decided to expand the system and make school have more grades. The problems began when they began adding less practical subjects, like history, science and foreign languages. These subjects can’t be taught as effectively through this system, because they are often more fact-based and less skill-based. Like history for example, requires knowledge of certain facts to do well. So what happens is, students will cram for a test and forgot everything shortly afterward. I’d say this is true for the sciences as well. On foreign languages, true learning requires immersion. Written tests simply aren’t very useful for it so almost no one learns a foreign language through school. There are alternatives to our system in other countries. Strangely enough, Germany, where the system we presently use was invented, offers many vocational options to students who want practical experience. Switzerland has a system like that too, where despite not having many college graduates, it’s one of the richest countries in Europe. Why won’t we change it to be more practical? I think it’s because in America we don’t like the idea of tracking people into certain career path. We believe that everyone should reach for the stars, which in our country means having an academically-oriented high school experience and going to college. And also, no one wants to say “don’t teach this or that” because it sounds mean or disrespectful to those who teach the subject. Hence, we have a lot of ideas on things that should be taught but not many on what should be cut from the curriculum, which is not a very useful place to be.

Like JDaniel Richer said. You aren’t learning important stuff←—I’ve experienced that myself. In high school. There’s barely any Certifications(ones that can be quite valuable) to take. Don’t expect the system to be reformed until 2100. A major portion what you are taught can be found online(I’m trying to find a simple answer to paying taxes) High school isn’t an adult place like it’s bragged about in elementary schools’ propaganda, it’s elementary school but for teenagers. Too many courses. Grade 9 and 10 English class were something I did enjoy because it did teach me things. Beyond grade 10 English was boring. In general, too many electives and compulsories. When it came to freshmen, I had to take lots of courses I though I finally escaped from in elementary, BUT NOPE: I had to take English, French, Gym, Geo, Math and Sci) The amount of total courses per semester really dropped student’s motivations(We F****** had it by Senior year) You don’t have control of what your timetable looks like before the year even starts.. I know it’s liability reasons and others. But if you really wanted to treat students like adults. Why snitch their grades every time it gets changed? Not every students’ parents understands that one course has terrible grades because it’s not important and they took it to fill the gap and not every parent is understanding/helpful, I’ve came across students(I’ve experienced this myself) who come to class in a robot/zombie mood because they’ve spent a majority of after school hours in an argument war with their parents(Another reason why students barely talk about home problems with teachers or school staff because the parents will just put on a show when questioned)
